pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.1.1.pli: Tena samayena buddho bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmato upanandassa sakyaputtassa upaṭṭhāko mahāmatto āyasmato upanandassa sakyaputtassa dūtena cīvaracetāpannaṃ pāhesi—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.1.2.eng: At that time a certain government official was a supporter of Venerable Upananda the Sakyan. On one occasion that official sent a robe fund by messenger, saying,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.1.3.pli: “iminā cīvaracetāpannena cīvaraṃ cetāpetvā ayyaṃ upanandaṃ cīvarena acchādehī”ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.1.3.eng: “Buy robe-cloth with this fund and give it to Venerable Upananda.”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.1.4.pli: Atha kho so dūto yenāyasmā upanando sakyaputto tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ upanandaṃ sakyaputtaṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.1.4.eng: The messenger went to Upananda and said,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.1.5.pli: “idaṃ kho, bhante, āyasmantaṃ uddissa cīvaracetāpannaṃ ābhataṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.1.5.eng: “Venerable, I’ve brought a robe fund for you.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.1.7.pli: Evaṃ vutte āyasmā upanando sakyaputto taṃ dūtaṃ etadavoca—

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.1.8.pli: “na kho mayaṃ, āvuso, cīvaracetāpannaṃ paṭiggaṇhāma, cīvarañca kho mayaṃ paṭiggaṇhāma kālena kappiyan”ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.1.8.eng: “We don’t receive robe funds, but we do receive allowable robe-cloth at the right time.”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.1.9.pli: Evaṃ vutte, so dūto āyasmantaṃ upanandaṃ sakyaputtaṃ etadavoca—

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.1.10.eng: “Is there anyone who provides services for you?”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.1.11.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññataro upāsako ārāmaṃ agamāsi kenacideva karaṇīyena.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.1.11.eng: Just then a lay follower had come to the monastery on some business.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.1.12.pli: Atha kho āyasmā upanando sakyaputto taṃ dūtaṃ etadavoca—

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.1.13.eng: “This lay follower provides services for the monks.”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.1.14.pli: Atha kho so dūto taṃ upāsakaṃ saññāpetvā yenāyasmā upanando sakyaputto tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ upanandaṃ sakyaputtaṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.1.14.eng: The messenger instructed that lay follower and then returned to Upananda, saying,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.1.15.pli: “yaṃ kho, bhante, āyasmā veyyāvaccakaraṃ niddisi saññatto so mayā.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.1.15.eng: “I’ve instructed the lay follower you pointed out to me.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.1.16.pli: Upasaṅkamatu āyasmā kālena, cīvarena taṃ acchādessatī”ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.1.16.eng: Please go to them at the right time and they’ll give you robe-cloth.”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.1.17.pli: Tena kho pana samayena so mahāmatto āyasmato upanandassa sakyaputtassa santike dūtaṃ pāhesi—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.1.17.eng: Later on that government official sent a message to Upananda, saying,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.1.18.pli: “paribhuñjatu ayyo taṃ cīvaraṃ, icchāma mayaṃ ayyena taṃ cīvaraṃ paribhuttan”ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.1.18.eng: “Please use the robe-cloth. I would like you to use the robe-cloth.”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.1.19.pli: Atha kho āyasmā upanando sakyaputto taṃ upāsakaṃ na kiñci avacāsi.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.1.19.eng: When Upananda did not say anything to that lay follower,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.1.20.pli: Dutiyampi kho so mahāmatto āyasmato upanandassa sakyaputtassa santike dūtaṃ pāhesi—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.1.20.eng: that government official sent him a second message

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.1.21.pli: “paribhuñjatu ayyo taṃ cīvaraṃ, icchāma mayaṃ ayyena taṃ cīvaraṃ paribhuttan”ti.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.1.22.pli: Dutiyampi kho āyasmā upanando sakyaputto taṃ upāsakaṃ na kiñci avacāsi.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.1.22.eng: When Upananda still did not say anything to that lay follower,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.1.23.pli: Tatiyampi kho so mahāmatto āyasmato upanandassa sakyaputtassa santike dūtaṃ pāhesi—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.1.23.eng: that government official sent him a third message.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.1.24.pli: “paribhuñjatu ayyo taṃ cīvaraṃ, icchāma mayaṃ ayyena taṃ cīvaraṃ paribhuttan”ti.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena negamassa samayo hoti.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.2.2.pli: Negamena ca katikā katā hoti— “yo pacchā āgacchati paññāsaṃ baddho”ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.2.2.eng: At that time the householder association had made an agreement that whoever came late to a meeting would be fined fifty coins. And now they were having a meeting.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.2.3.pli: Atha kho āyasmā upanando sakyaputto yena so upāsako tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā taṃ upāsakaṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.2.3.eng: Just then Upananda went to that lay follower and said,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.2.5.eng: “Please wait one day, venerable, for today there’s a meeting of the householder association.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.2.6.pli: Negamena ca katikā katā hoti—‘yo pacchā āgacchati paññāsaṃ baddho’”ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.2.6.eng: They’ve made an agreement that whoever comes late gets fined fifty coins.”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.2.7.pli: “Ajjeva me, āvuso, cīvaraṃ dehī”ti ovaṭṭikāya parāmasi.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.2.7.eng: Saying, “Give me the robe-cloth today,” he grabbed him by the belt.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.2.8.pli: Atha kho so upāsako āyasmatā upanandena sakyaputtena nippīḷiyamāno āyasmato upanandassa sakyaputtassa cīvaraṃ cetāpetvā pacchā agamāsi.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.2.8.eng: Being pressured by Upananda, the lay follower bought him robe-cloth, and as a consequence he was late for the meeting.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.2.10.pli: “kissa tvaṃ, ayyo, pacchā āgato, paññāsaṃ jīnosī”ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.2.10.eng: “Sir, why are you late? You’ve just lost fifty coins.”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.2.11.pli: Atha kho so upāsako tesaṃ manussānaṃ etamatthaṃ ārocesi.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.2.11.eng: When that lay follower told them what had happened,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.2.13.eng: “These Sakyan monastics have great desires. They’re not content.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.2.14.eng: It’s no easy matter to provide them with a service.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.2.15.eng: How could Venerable Upananda not agree when asked by a lay follower

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.2.17.pli: Assosuṃ kho bhikkhū tesaṃ manussānaṃ ujjhāyantānaṃ khiyyantānaṃ vipācentānaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.2.17.eng: The monks heard the complaints of those people,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.2.18.pli: Ye te bhikkhū appicchā …pe… te ujjhāyanti khiyyanti vipācenti—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.2.18.eng: and the monks of few desires complained and criticized him,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.2.19.eng: “How could Venerable Upananda not agree when asked by a lay follower

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.2.21.pli: Atha kho te bhikkhū āyasmantaṃ upanandaṃ sakyaputtaṃ anekapariyāyena vigarahitvā bhagavato etamatthaṃ ārocesuṃ …pe…
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.2.21.eng: After rebuking him in many ways, they told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned Upananda:

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.2.22.eng: “Is it true, Upananda, that you did this?”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.2.26.eng: “Foolish man, how could you do this?

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.2.29.pli: evañca pana, bhikkhave, imaṃ sikkhāpadaṃ uddiseyyātha—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.2.29.eng: “And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.3.1.pli: “Bhikkhuṃ paneva uddissa rājā vā rājabhoggo vā brāhmaṇo vā gahapatiko vā dūtena cīvaracetāpannaṃ pahiṇeyya—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.3.1.eng: ‘If a king, a king’s employee, a brahmin, or a householder sends a robe fund for a monk by messenger, saying,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.3.2.pli: ‘iminā cīvaracetāpannena cīvaraṃ cetāpetvā itthannāmaṃ bhikkhuṃ cīvarena acchādehī’ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.3.2.eng: “Buy robe-cloth with this robe fund and give it to monk so-and-so,”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.3.3.pli: So ce dūto taṃ bhikkhuṃ upasaṅkamitvā evaṃ vadeyya—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.3.3.eng: and the messenger goes to that monk and says,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.3.4.pli: ‘idaṃ kho, bhante, āyasmantaṃ uddissa cīvaracetāpannaṃ ābhataṃ, paṭiggaṇhātu āyasmā cīvaracetāpannan’ti,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.3.4.eng: “Venerable, I have brought a robe fund for you. Please receive it,”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.3.5.pli: tena bhikkhunā so dūto evamassa vacanīyo—

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.3.6.pli: ‘na kho mayaṃ, āvuso, cīvaracetāpannaṃ paṭiggaṇhāma. Cīvarañca kho mayaṃ paṭiggaṇhāma, kālena kappiyan’ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.3.6.eng: ‘We don’t receive robe funds, but we do receive allowable robe-cloth at the right time.’

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.3.7.pli: So ce dūto taṃ bhikkhuṃ evaṃ vadeyya—

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.3.8.eng: “Is there anyone who provides services for you?”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.3.9.pli: cīvaratthikena, bhikkhave, bhikkhunā veyyāvaccakaro niddisitabbo ārāmiko vā upāsako vā—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.3.9.eng: the monk, if he needs robe-cloth, should point out a monastery worker or a lay follower and say,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.3.11.pli: So ce dūto taṃ veyyāvaccakaraṃ saññāpetvā taṃ bhikkhuṃ upasaṅkamitvā evaṃ vadeyya—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.3.11.eng: If the messenger instructs that service provider and then returns to the monk and says,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.3.12.pli: ‘yaṃ kho, bhante, āyasmā veyyāvaccakaraṃ niddisi saññatto so mayā, upasaṅkamatu āyasmā kālena, cīvarena taṃ acchādessatī’ti,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.3.12.eng: “Venerable, I have instructed the service provider you pointed out. Please go to them at the right time and they’ll give you robe-cloth,”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.3.13.pli: cīvaratthikena, bhikkhave, bhikkhunā veyyāvaccakaro upasaṅkamitvā dvattikkhattuṃ codetabbo sāretabbo—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.3.13.eng: then, if that monk needs robe-cloth, he should go to that service provider and prompt them and remind them two or three times, saying,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.3.15.pli: Dvattikkhattuṃ codayamāno sārayamāno taṃ cīvaraṃ abhinipphādeyya, iccetaṃ kusalaṃ;
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.3.15.eng: If he then gets robe-cloth, all is well.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.3.16.pli: no ce abhinipphādeyya, catukkhattuṃ pañcakkhattuṃ chakkhattuparamaṃ tuṇhībhūtena uddissa ṭhātabbaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.3.16.eng: If he does not get it, he should stand in silence for it at most six times.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.3.17.pli: Catukkhattuṃ pañcakkhattuṃ chakkhattuparamaṃ tuṇhībhūto uddissa tiṭṭhamāno taṃ cīvaraṃ abhinipphādeyya, iccetaṃ kusalaṃ;
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.3.17.eng: If he then gets robe-cloth, all is well.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.3.18.pli: tato ce uttari vāyamamāno taṃ cīvaraṃ abhinipphādeyya, nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.3.18.eng: If he makes any further effort and then gets robe-cloth, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.3.19.pli: No ce abhinipphādeyya, yatassa cīvaracetāpannaṃ ābhataṃ, tattha sāmaṃ vā gantabbaṃ dūto vā pāhetabbo—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.3.19.eng: If he does not get robe-cloth, he should go to the owners of that robe fund, or send a message, saying,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.3.20.pli: ‘yaṃ kho tumhe āyasmanto bhikkhuṃ uddissa cīvaracetāpannaṃ pahiṇittha, na taṃ tassa bhikkhuno kiñci atthaṃ anubhoti,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.3.20.eng: “That monk hasn’t received any benefit from the robe fund you sent for him.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.3.21.pli: yuñjantāyasmanto sakaṃ, mā vo sakaṃ vinassā’ti,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:1.3.21.eng: Please recover what’s yours, or it might perish.”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.1.2.pli: bhikkhussatthāya, bhikkhuṃ ārammaṇaṃ karitvā, bhikkhuṃ acchādetukāmo.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.1.2.eng: for the benefit of a monk; making a monk the object of consideration, one wants to give to him.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.1.6.eng: whoever gets food and wages from a king.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.1.10.pli: ṭhapetvā rājaṃ rājabhoggaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ avaseso gahapatiko nāma.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.1.10.eng: anyone apart from a king, a king’s employee, and a brahmin.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.1.12.pli: hiraññaṃ vā suvaṇṇaṃ vā muttā vā maṇi vā.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.1.12.eng: money, gold, a pearl, or a gem.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.1.14.eng: with that which is at one’s disposal.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.1.19.pli: So ce dūto taṃ bhikkhuṃ upasaṅkamitvā evaṃ vadeyya—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.1.19.eng: And the messenger goes to that monk and says,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.1.20.pli: “idaṃ kho, bhante, āyasmantaṃ uddissa cīvaracetāpannaṃ ābhataṃ. Paṭiggaṇhātu āyasmā cīvaracetāpannan”ti,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.1.20.eng: “Venerable, I have brought a robe fund for you. Please receive it,”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.1.21.pli: tena bhikkhunā so dūto evamassa vacanīyo—

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.1.22.pli: “na kho mayaṃ, āvuso, cīvaracetāpannaṃ paṭiggaṇhāma. Cīvarañca kho mayaṃ paṭiggaṇhāma, kālena kappiyan”ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.1.22.eng: “We don’t receive robe funds, but we do receive allowable robe-cloth at the right time.”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.1.23.pli: So ce dūto taṃ bhikkhuṃ evaṃ vadeyya—

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.1.24.eng: “Is there anyone who provides services for you?”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.1.25.pli: Cīvaratthikena, bhikkhave, bhikkhunā veyyāvaccakaro niddisitabbo ārāmiko vā upāsako vā—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.1.25.eng: the monk, if he needs robe-cloth, should point out a monastery worker or a lay follower and say,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.1.27.pli: Na vattabbo— “tassa dehīti vā, so vā nikkhipissati, so vā parivattessati, so vā cetāpessatī”ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.1.27.eng: he should not say, “Give it to them,” “They’ll put it aside,” “They’ll trade it,” “They’ll buy it.”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.1.28.pli: So ce dūto taṃ veyyāvaccakaraṃ saññāpetvā taṃ bhikkhuṃ upasaṅkamitvā evaṃ vadeyya—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.1.28.eng: If the messenger instructs that service provider and then returns to the monk and says,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.1.29.pli: “yaṃ kho, bhante, āyasmā veyyāvaccakaraṃ niddisi saññatto so mayā. Upasaṅkamatu āyasmā kālena, cīvarena taṃ acchādessatī”ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.1.29.eng: “Venerable, I have instructed the service provider you pointed out. Please go to them at the right time and they’ll give you robe-cloth,”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.1.30.pli: Cīvaratthikena, bhikkhave, bhikkhunā veyyāvaccakaro upasaṅkamitvā dvattikkhattuṃ codetabbo sāretabbo—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.1.30.eng: then, if that monk needs robe-cloth, he should go to that service provider and prompt them and remind them two or three times, saying,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.1.30.comm: “Prompt” renders codetabbo. For a discussion of the meaning of the verb codeti, see Appendix of Technical Terms.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.1.32.pli: Na vattabbo— “dehi me cīvaraṃ, āhara me cīvaraṃ, parivattehi me cīvaraṃ, cetāpehi me cīvaran”ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.1.32.eng: he should not say, “Give me robe-cloth,” “Get me robe-cloth,” “Trade me robe-cloth,” “Buy me robe-cloth.”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.1.33.eng: He should say it a second

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.1.35.eng: If he gets it, all is well.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.1.36.pli: no ce abhinipphādeti, tattha gantvā tuṇhībhūtena uddissa ṭhātabbaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.1.36.eng: If he does not get it, he should go there and stand in silence for it:

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.1.37.pli: Na āsane nisīditabbaṃ. Na āmisaṃ paṭiggahetabbaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.1.37.eng: he should not sit down on a seat; he should not receive food;

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.1.38.eng: he should not give a teaching.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.1.39.eng: If he is asked, “Why have you come?” he should say, “Think about it.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.1.39.comm: Jānāhi. This verb, which normally means “to understand” or “to find out”, is very flexible in its usage.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.1.40.pli: Sace āsane vā nisīdati, āmisaṃ vā paṭiggaṇhāti, dhammaṃ vā bhāsati, ṭhānaṃ bhañjati.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.1.40.eng: If he sits down on a seat, or he receives food, or he gives a teaching, he loses one allowance to stand.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.1.43.eng: If he prompts four times, he can stand four times.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.1.43.comm: The point here and below is that each prompting is equivalent to two standings. You can choose one or the other.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.1.44.eng: If he prompts five times, he can stand twice.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.1.45.eng: If he prompts six times, he cannot stand at all.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.2.1.pli: Tato ce uttari vāyamamāno taṃ cīvaraṃ abhinipphādeti,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.2.1.eng: If he makes any further effort and then gets robe-cloth:

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.2.2.eng: for the effort there is an act of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.2.3.eng: When he gets the robe-cloth, it becomes subject to relinquishment.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.2.4.pli: Nissajjitabbaṃ saṅghassa vā gaṇassa vā puggalassa vā.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.2.4.eng: The robe-cloth should be relinquished to a sangha, a group, or an individual.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.2.5.eng: “And, monks, it should be relinquished like this. …

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.2.6.eng: (To be expanded as in Bu NP 1:3.2.5–3.2.29, with appropriate substitutions.)

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.2.7.pli: “idaṃ me, bhante, cīvaraṃ atirekatikkhattuṃ codanāya atirekachakkhattuṃ ṭhānena abhinipphāditaṃ nissaggiyaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.2.7.eng: ‘Venerables, this robe-cloth, which I got after prompting more than three times and standing more than six times, is to be relinquished.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.2.8.eng: I relinquish it to the Sangha.’ …

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.2.11.eng: ‘I give this robe-cloth back to you.’”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.2.12.pli: No ce abhinipphādeyya, yatassa cīvaracetāpannaṃ ābhataṃ tattha sāmaṃ vā gantabbaṃ dūto vā pāhetabbo—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.2.12.eng: If he does not get robe-cloth, he should go to the owner of that robe fund, or send a message, saying,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.2.13.pli: “yaṃ kho tumhe, āyasmanto, bhikkhuṃ uddissa cīvaracetāpannaṃ pahiṇittha na taṃ tassa bhikkhuno kiñci atthaṃ anubhoti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.2.13.eng: “That monk hasn’t received any benefit from the robe fund you sent for him.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.2.14.pli: Yuñjantāyasmanto sakaṃ, mā vo sakaṃ vinassā”ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.2.14.eng: Please recover what’s yours, or it might perish.”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.3.1.pli: Atirekatikkhattuṃ codanāya atirekachakkhattuṃ ṭhānena atirekasaññī abhinipphādeti, nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.3.1.eng: If he prompts more than three times and stands more than six times, and he perceives it as more, and he gets robe-cloth, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.3.2.pli: Atirekatikkhattuṃ codanāya atirekachakkhattuṃ ṭhānena vematiko abhinipphādeti, nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.3.2.eng: If he prompts more than three times and stands more than six times, but he is unsure of it, and he gets robe-cloth, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.3.3.pli: Atirekatikkhattuṃ codanāya atirekachakkhattuṃ ṭhānena ūnakasaññī abhinipphādeti, nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.3.3.eng: If he prompts more than three times and stands more than six times, but he perceives it as less, and he gets robe-cloth, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.3.4.pli: Ūnakatikkhattuṃ codanāya ūnakachakkhattuṃ ṭhānena atirekasaññī, āpatti dukkaṭassa.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.3.4.eng: If he prompts less than three times and stands less than six times, but he perceives it as more, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.3.5.pli: Ūnakatikkhattuṃ codanāya ūnakachakkhattuṃ ṭhānena vematiko, āpatti dukkaṭassa.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.3.5.eng: If he prompts less than three times and stands less than six times, but he is unsure of it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.3.6.pli: Ūnakatikkhattuṃ codanāya ūnakachakkhattuṃ ṭhānena ūnakasaññī anāpatti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.3.6.eng: If he prompts less than three times and stands less than six times, and he perceives it as less, there is no offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.4.2.eng: if he prompts three times and stands six times;

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.4.3.eng: if he prompts less than three times and stands less than six times;

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.4.4.eng: if it is given without prompting;

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.4.5.eng: if the owners prompt and then it is given;
pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.4.5.comm: I translate according to the gloss in Kkh: sāmikehi codetvā dinne, “After prompting by the owners, it is given.”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.4.7.eng: if he is the first offender.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.4.8.eng: The training rule on kings, the tenth, is finished.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.4.9.eng: The first subchapter on the robe season is finished.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np10:2.4.13.eng: Three on those who are unrelated,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:1.1.pli: Tena samayena buddho bhagavā āḷaviyaṃ viharati aggāḷave cetiye.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:1.1.eng: At one time when the Buddha was staying at Āḷavī at the Aggāḷava Shrine,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyā bhikkhū kosiyakārake upasaṅkamitvā evaṃ vadanti—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:1.2.eng: the monks from the group of six went to silk-makers and said,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:1.3.eng: “Please boil a heap of silkworms and give us silk.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:1.4.eng: We want to make a blanket containing silk.”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:1.5.eng: The silk-makers complained and criticized them,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:1.6.pli: “kathañhi nāma samaṇā sakyaputtiyā amhe upasaṅkamitvā evaṃ vakkhanti—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:1.6.eng: “How can the Sakyan monastics come and say

pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:1.7.pli: ‘bahū, āvuso, kosakārake pacatha, amhākampi dassatha, mayampi icchāma kosiyamissakaṃ santhataṃ kātun’ti.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:1.8.pli: Amhākampi alābhā, amhākampi dulladdhaṃ, ye mayaṃ ājīvassa hetu puttadārassa kāraṇā bahū khuddake pāṇe saṅghātaṃ āpādemā”ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:1.8.eng: It’s our misfortune that we must kill many small creatures because of our livelihoods and because of our wives and children.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:1.8.comm: “Children” renders putta/ā. In Pali the male gender takes precedent if a group contains people of both sexes. For instance, the plural puttā, “sons”, may mean “children” or “offsping”, depending on the context. In the same way, the plural bhātāro, “brothers”, can mean “siblings”. This way of understanding male-gender nouns is confirmed in the introduction to the Pali lexical work the Abhidhānappadīpikāṭīkā: Ettha hi mātā ca pitā ca pitaro, putto ca dhītā ca puttā, sassu ca sasuro ca sasurā, bhātā ca bhaginī ca bhātaroti bhinnaliṅgānampi ekaseso dassitoti, “‘Mother and father are fathers; son and daughter are sons; mother-in-law and father-in-law are fathers-in-law; brother and sister are brothers;’ in this case the split gender is shown with only one gender remaining.” The Abhidhānappadīpikāṭīkā is available online at tipitaka.org.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:1.9.pli: Assosuṃ kho bhikkhū tesaṃ manussānaṃ ujjhāyantānaṃ khiyyantānaṃ vipācentānaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:1.9.eng: The monks heard the complaints of those silk-makers,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:1.10.pli: Ye te bhikkhū appicchā …pe… te ujjhāyanti khiyyanti vipācenti—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:1.10.eng: and the monks of few desires complained and criticized those monks,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:1.11.pli: “kathañhi nāma chabbaggiyā bhikkhū kosiyakārake upasaṅkamitvā evaṃ vakkhanti—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:1.11.eng: “How could the monks from the group of six go to silk-makers and say

pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:1.12.pli: ‘bahū, āvuso, kosakārake pacatha, amhākampi dassatha, mayampi icchāma kosiyamissakaṃ santhataṃ kātun’”ti.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:1.13.pli: Atha kho te bhikkhū chabbaggiye bhikkhū anekapariyāyena vigarahitvā bhagavato etamatthaṃ ārocesuṃ …pe…
pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:1.13.eng: After rebuking them in many ways, they told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned the monks:

pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:1.14.pli: “saccaṃ kira tumhe, bhikkhave, kosiyakārake upasaṅkamitvā evaṃ vadetha—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:1.14.eng: “Is it true, monks, that you did this?”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:1.19.pli: kathañhi nāma tumhe, moghapurisā, kosiyakārake upasaṅkamitvā evaṃ vakkhatha—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:1.19.eng: “Foolish men, how could you do this?

pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:1.20.pli: ‘bahū, āvuso, kosakārake pacatha, amhākampi dassatha, mayampi icchāma kosiyamissakaṃ santhataṃ kātun’ti.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:1.22.pli: evañca pana, bhikkhave, imaṃ sikkhāpadaṃ uddiseyyātha—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:1.22.eng: “And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:

pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:1.23.1.pli: “Yo pana bhikkhu kosiyamissakaṃ santhataṃ kārāpeyya, nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyan”ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:1.23.1.eng: ‘If a monk has a blanket made that contains silk, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.’”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:2.1.4.eng: … The monk who has been given the full ordination by a unanimous Sangha through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is irreversible and fit to stand—this sort of monk is meant in this case.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:2.1.6.eng: it is made by strewing, not by weaving.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:2.1.6.comm: For the method of making a santhata, see Appendix of Technical Terms.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:2.1.8.pli: ekenapi kosiyaṃsunā missitvā karoti vā kārāpeti vā, payoge dukkaṭaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:2.1.8.eng: If he makes a blanket that contains even one thread of silk, or he has one made, then for the effort there is an act of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:2.1.9.eng: When he gets the blanket, it becomes subject to relinquishment.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:2.1.10.pli: Nissajjitabbaṃ saṅghassa vā gaṇassa vā puggalassa vā.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:2.1.10.eng: The blanket should be relinquished to a sangha, a group, or an individual.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:2.1.11.eng: “And, monks, it should be relinquished like this.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:2.1.12.eng: (To be expanded as in Bu NP 1:3.2.5–3.2.29, with appropriate substitutions.)

pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:2.1.13.pli: idaṃ me, bhante, kosiyamissakaṃ santhataṃ kārāpitaṃ nissaggiyaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:2.1.13.eng: ‘Venerables, this blanket containing silk, which I got made, is to be relinquished.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:2.1.14.eng: I relinquish it to the Sangha.’ …

pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:2.1.17.eng: ‘I give this blanket back to you.’”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:2.2.1.pli: Attanā vippakataṃ attanā pariyosāpeti, nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:2.2.1.eng: If he finishes what he began himself, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:2.2.2.pli: Attanā vippakataṃ parehi pariyosāpeti, nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:2.2.2.eng: If he has others finish what he began himself, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:2.2.3.pli: Parehi vippakataṃ attanā pariyosāpeti, nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:2.2.3.eng: If he finishes himself what was begun by others, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:2.2.4.pli: Parehi vippakataṃ parehi pariyosāpeti, nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:2.2.4.eng: If he has others finish what was begun by others, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:2.2.5.pli: Aññassatthāya karoti vā kārāpeti vā, āpatti dukkaṭassa.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:2.2.5.eng: If he makes one, or has one made, for someone else, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:2.2.6.pli: Aññena kataṃ paṭilabhitvā paribhuñjati, āpatti dukkaṭassa.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:2.2.6.eng: If he gets one that was made by someone else and then uses it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:2.2.8.pli: vitānaṃ vā bhūmattharaṇaṃ vā sāṇipākāraṃ vā bhisiṃ vā bibbohanaṃ vā karoti,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:2.2.8.eng: if he makes a canopy, a floor cover, a cloth screen, a mattress, or a pillow;

pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:2.2.10.eng: if he is the first offender.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:2.2.11.eng: The training rule on silk, the first, is finished.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np11:2.2.11.comm: It is called the first rule since it is the first rule of the second chapter of nissaggiya pācittiyas for monks. If, however, one disregards the division into chapters, it is the eleventh rule of the nissaggiya pācittiyas.
